instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesn’t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with couple of keys not working
threads.message:
Have a headache-inducing <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had no liquid damage, but the keyboard wasn't working properly (keys 7,8,9,u,i,o,j,k,l,m, comma, period, left and right arrow) not working. sometimes, when i press the m-key, the trackpad registers a click (whatever the cursor is pointing at, gets clicked upon key-press)

Of course i suspected the customer probably díd spill something, so tried a known-good keyboard, but no dice.
Have ofcourse tried several other new keyboards (4 in total), but the symptoms are the same.

I have tried two different J5713s and have tried swapping the <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> with another one (only once, so might try again).

Was wondering if anyone knows which <SIGNAL>WS_KBD</SIGNAL> lines i should suspect, since it seems pretty obvious to me that one set of them should be the culprit.
I cannot find any documentation on which lines represent which keys.

anybody have some pointers?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with couple of keys not working
threads.message: Also, have checked all traces from J5713 to <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> and all of them have continuity.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with couple of keys not working
threads.message:
Jesus on a stick holy mother of god...
I am actually too embarassed to share this, but for the sake of helping clueless souls like myself i will share my being abso-fucking-lutely trolled by this Mac:

There is a software-'feature' called 'mouse keys'...
It was ticked under System-preferences. 
This can be triggered (if enabled) by pressing the Alt-key 5 times in a row.

My fucking god. I swear, I'm going to throw myself against the wall for measuring and soldering on this fucking board.


I am so humbled.. hope someone with similar issues will find this thread before prodding around as much as i have.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with couple of keys not working
threads.message: Yeah and this is why you always boot from USB with your known good OSX.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with couple of keys not working
threads.message: Yep also why i shouldn’t be working on more macs then I have bootables at the same time. :)
